--- title: Obturator Internus Muscle (OI) --- # Overview ::: {#tbl-oian-obturator-internus .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Obturator Internus Obturator membrane and its bony boundaries Medial surface of Greater Trochanter Nerve to Obturator internus
L5 - S1		 Hip: ER, Extension, Abduction, Stabilization
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Inner surface of the obturator membrane and its bony boundaries @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} Medial surface of the greater trochanter @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} Sacral plexus ([L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}}), [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - External rotation and extension of the hip joint (also active in abduction, depending on the joint’s position) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Stabilizes hip joint -DrK # Function “Ultrasound ­guided EMG analysis of the obturator internus and several other external rotator muscles in 10 human subjects.98 The obturator internus was usually the first muscle to become active during a gradually increasing isometric effort to abduct and externally rotate the hip.” @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 # Stretch Child's Pose stretch can be used to stretch the Obturator Internus muscle. By cueing the knees to stay straight instead of moving into hip ER, this better stretches the obturator internus.
